objdescid.origination: Edward John Chance author, inventor, delineator. Blake wrote this receipt, and "Edwd. Jno. Chance" signed it as witness (see object note).

provenance.name: Yale University Library
provenance.note: John Linnell; from the Linnell collection; sold at Christie's, Dec. 2, 1938 to the dealer W. H. Robinson on behalf on Otis T. Bradley (in Lot 62 £78 15s); presented to Yale University Library by Mr. Otis T. Bradley in 1941 or 1942.

repository.department: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

desc.objtitle:
14 July 1826 Receipt, John Linnell, 14 July 1826,
Object 1 (Bentley Receipt 43)

objnote.p: Blake wrote this receipt, and "Edwd. Jno. Chance" signed it as witness. Keynes (*Letters*, page 161) identifies this signature and witness as Edward John Chance, a son-in-law of John Linnell.

To the left of the text is an embossed revenue stamp depicting a coronet and sprigs of long, narrow leaves on its left and right. The word “RECEIPT” appears at the top and the words “TWO SHILLING/SIX PENCE” at the center.

lg.l: Recievd Received of MrJohn Linnell. the Sum of One
Hundred & fifty Pounds for the Copy-right & Plates
(Twenty-two in number) of the Book of Job. Publishd Published
March 1825by Me.William Blake Author of the Work
